title: Of the seven Russian CEOs and government leaders listed below, how many will cease to hold their current positions by 1 July 2018?
preds: Just going to 100 because there's just over a week left.
Rusal not on the list was lucky.
Shifting toward none because there's only a few weeks left.

Dmitry Medvedev (Prime Minister) - Ok,
 Dmitry Kozak (Deputy Prime Minister) - Ok,
 Sergey Shoygu (Defense Minister) - Ok, 
Alexander Bastrykin (Investigative Committee leader) - Ok, 
Nikolai Patrushev (Head, Security Council of Russia) - Ok, 
Igor Sechin (Rosneft CEO) - Ok, https://news.rambler.ru/business/39750492-v-rosnefti-ne-podtverdili-perehod-sechina-v-pravitelstvo/
Alexey Miller (Gazprom CEO) - Ok in sanction list
Shifting a few points toward 0-1 because there are only two months left and all of these people are still in their respective jobs.

Going more aggressive to 99-1 from 95-5 given WocPoT. Election over. Economy is crap and will stay crap. All close mates and loyalists of Tsar VladyPooTeena Ze Shirtless. I can foresee  one having to leave to take the blame for Trumpy meddling to appease Trumpy. That blackmail of the #PeePeeTape hasn't come out, unless Putina is saving it for maximum effect.  Perhaps one will die, either naturally or artificially with some military grade artificial PooTeen poison, if so then will have to switch to 75-25.

After re-election, there might be less need for Putin to show his force by removing high-ranking allies (thereby signalling to potential contenders for power that no-one is safe and he is watching everyone that could be a threat to him). Also, with the Skripal-scandal, focus currently seems on foreign policy and less on internal matters. With the football world cup starting in mid-June, Russian leadership has a strong interest to produce a relative political calm before the games start - towards internal and external actors.
With the recent election results, and current international pressure on Russia, stability in leadership is probably the likeliest near-term response from Russia.

Recently resigned governor Tulayev not on this list, but suggestive of turmoil? Or is this purely on account of the mall fire? Dateline 4-2-2018 Scott Rose Verified account @rprose
 1h1 hour ago
With Tuleyev's resignation over the weekend, there are just two Russian governors remaining who predate Putin: Belgorod region's Yevgeny Savchenko, in office since Dec. 1993 (!)
Lipetsk region's Oleg Korolyov, in office since April 1998

So of the four allies mentioned in the question who have already been removed, three are former KGB officials from St. Petersburg and the fourth, Vladimir Yakunin, officially retired. With that in mind, of the seven mentioned only Nikolai Patrushev worked in the KGB so I think he is the most likely to go. The rest of these guys are either career bureaucrats or soldiers and lack independent power bases.
Putin will have to deal with liquidity and security, requiring a new measure of loyalty.

A possibility of some changes 1-3 prior to Putin's reelection to demonstrate the appearance of change. He's already replaced many Oblast Governors for this purpose.  There may be some Putin post-election changes so he can better consolidate power too.
Maybe after the election. (First round 18 March; second round 8 April.)

Since mid-2015, Russian President Vladimir Putin has removed from prominent positions four close allies: Sergei Ivanov, Andrei Belyaninov, Viktor Ivanov, and Vladimir Yakunin. The Oligarchs of Russian society have a significant amount of influence, and as there are protests and increasing critiques of Putin from the populous, I think Putin will look for ways to decrease the number of individuals who could wield any level of influence / power over his actions. The interesting thing is that the US Treasury just released a list of the most prominent Russian "Oligarchs" with connections to Putin, which might put increased pressure on Putin to pull back on any rapid, significant changes he would want to make. Because of this, the percentages I give are - 43% 0-1 leaders removed; 48% 2-3 leaders removed; 8% chance of 4-5 leaders being removed and 1% chance of 6-7 leaders being removed. Article: https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/30/us-treasury-releases-list-of-russian-oligarchs-linked-to-putin.html
Putin will make moves to consolidate power even further, especially as protests break out, but so many are dependent on him already, which means they are right where he wants them.

I’m thinking minimal changes. Miller, Sechin, Patrushev, Bastrykin, and Shoigu all seem safe. Kozak likely ok. Medvedev not well liked and may become a sacricial lamb - but I’m sure he’ll keep that duckhouse!
Maybe more changes after the election?
Instability in Russia makes cosmetic changes necessary.
Tsar Vlad the Shirtless always seems to know how much pressure to bleed off without upsetting the kleptocracy.

New polls show there to be record satisfaction with Putin's rule - pubilic confidence rating 57,7%. Shoigu seems to be well liked also (18%) while Medvedev is still on the chopping block (12,9%). Increasing my 0 to 1 and 2 to 3 brackets a little. http://tass.com/society/984606

Vlad the Shirtless likes to do some shuffling just before or just after elections, coming up some time in Spring, as I recall.  However, by now I think it fairly likely that he's got most folks in the jobs he wants them in, so maybe less this time.  In a real country, I would start to look at the reshuffling for signs that he is grooming a successor, but people like Putin think they're never to die or retire or get the boot.
Time for some change...but not too much. Putin master of redirection/ensuring pressure doesn’t build.
Putin and potus have several things in common and the most prevalent is 'revenge' on an enemy (made up or otherwise).

Each individual carries a party line. The one that had trouble in the past resigned from the position...but he is still in the position...and that same individual leads the investigating committee. Some of these are possibly heirs to Putin as well (for now).

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-election-putin-analysis/putin-plan-to-rejuvenate-russian-politics-makes-slow-progress-idUSKBN1DK14E
I think he has generally got folks set up the way he wants them for a while.  I am probably wrong.

Increasing the likelihoods of a major shuffle or a regime collapse. http://www.businessinsider.com/russia-looks-to-prospect-of-future-without-vladimir-putin-as-sources-say-he-has-considered-quitting-2017-11

My prediction is based on such calculations:
•	In general there has been ≈ 1,37 changes in the seven positions per year since Putin became a high government official (1999-2017)
•	On the years of presidental election (2000, 2004, 2008, 2012) the average change in the seven positions has been 2,275.
•	Taken into account that the end deadline of the prediction is half a year into 2018 I have taken the base rate to be average of the presidential year + normal year/2 = 1.8225. Hence I see that it is most likely that there will be 2 of more changes in the seven positions. It is however almost as likely that there will be less than 2 changes to these positions (it is however less likely there will be none). 4 to 5 changes I would see happening in a negative force majeure situation where numerous people holding these positions are seen to have been incompetent in dealing with the situation (e.g. a large country-wide protest movements, natural disaster). 6 to 7 changes I imagine would only happen in a case of regime collapse or possibly Putin discovering/suspecting coup d'etat (initiating Stalin like purges). As of who would be the most likely candidates I have somewhat struggled. I agree with @rids101 I think the most likely candidate would be Alezander Bastrykin having had numerous negative implications recently and himself having little powerbase. Good articles are the ones that that he has shared that give insight into Bastrykin's shaky position. However regarding Dmitri Medvedev I am not as confident. He has had his problems this year but the two recent research papers on Putin's inner circle have placed him to have the most strong position after 2018 presidential elections (see links below). However he would be an easy scapegoat in case Putin wanted to boost his own popularity or blame someone for a negative event just before the elections. There is also been speculation that Putin is will be looking to introduce into the high government positions new more younger officials who on the other hand are more dependent on Putin and thus could be viewed more loyal (Anton Vaino; Alexey Dyumin, Dmitry Mironov & Yevgeny Zinichev trio all who became governors of important regions). Some of these "new guard" could also threaten Medvedev's position especially post 2018 elections.
http://minchenko.ru/en/insights/analitics_18.html
https://fpp.spb.ru/fpp-top-successors (Google Translate)
http://carnegieendowment.org/files/Article_Kolesnikov_4_srok_2017_Eng_3.pdf  I myself also see Kozak as a possible person to change position. He apparently is not well liked by others in Putins inner circle. Also is deeply involved in Crimea project which however is costing RUS money and has had its problems. On the other hand he has been named as Putin's "project guy" - someone who Putin can trust to run large scale projects - Sochi Olympics, Crimea.
http://www.worldpolicy.org/blog/2016/10/24/crimea-becoming-russian-money-pit  Shoigu and Sechin are probably safe as they have been loyal and have had their fair amount of successes in previous years. It is possible that their positions could come more unstable under the aforementioned force majeure scenarios. Patrushev is hard to place. Has allegedly been given a new portfolio to deal with Balkans recently. However hardline in his approaches to West thus could become cumbersome in case a new "reset" with the West is attempted. Again hard to place his standings with Putin.
https://www.politico.eu/article/vladimir-putin-balkans-point-man-nikolai-patrushev/ With Miller there is very little information. Has been holding the position for quite some while, thus could assume has managed to do his job well. It would have made more sense to change him out when oil prices were down and Russia was struggling. Now however the prices are again rising and he can argue that he has managed to help Russia steer out of the rocky waters. Again hard to place his standing with Putin. Thanks again to @rids101 and also @ErikFritzsche. Both of their forecasts were a big help in tackling this question.

Igor Sechin seems like he's still got a seat at the table. Or a table anyway (Click link to see table.)
http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-11-05/did-russias-iranian-energy-deal-kill-four-birds-one-stone

Something of a swell of new appointments at the level of regional governors over the past couple of weeks. And also within United Russia: Among them, the former parliamentary faction leader was shifted to become the (acting) Governor of Dagestan (a big deal - and indeed a big task - for an ethnic Russian); while a somewhat controversial regional leader, Andrei Turchak (who has occasionally been talked about as a potential successor to Putin) has been elevated to become (as yet still acting) Chairman of the Party's General Council. So: no real major big name changes yet - but a lot of action at the level below the top. Leading me to rebalance my forecast slightly in favour of relatively more rather than relatively fewer changes.

Situation fluid.
Alex Kokcharov‏ @AlexKokcharov  20h20 hours ago
In 2017, the #Kremlin dismissed / made to resign 17 regional governors across #Russia. How many heads will roll?
http://www.rbc.ru/photoreport/28/09/2017/59cba8f79a794729827ab9de

My first forecast on this question, I am following @ErikFritzsche, given his track record and research interests.  I also am reacting to news that the head of Dagestan and three Russian governors just resigned. Time to start paying close attention to this question. @Rene @Censusguyz @praedico @Resonancia @Anneinak Dateline: three hours ago! https://frontnews.eu/news/en/14366/Three-governors-and-head-of-Dagestan-resigned-in-Russia

Barring natural death, they'll be there forever until they collapse, they're as thick as thieves. Oil would need to drop to <$40 a barrel. Russians are vodka drunk and spun up on paranoid nationalism, so have been neutered and won't try another revolution when they should.
new sanctions make shake things up some...

Looks to me like Putin has his ducks mostly lined up the way he wants them now.  If somebody offends him some way, or if a spot is needed for an up-and-coming lackey, a couple of heads may waft gently to earth, but I think no large-scale defenestrations just now.

A little late to the game with this one, luckily, it’s a long runner and most of the risk is probably piled up in next spring. Apologies if links have been linked before. First, I’m assuming that 1./ Putin will run (latest thinking is that he might run as an independent) and 2./ Putin will win. The probability of other options at this point seems small but would completely change everything I’m about to write.   @ErikFritzsche has a great analysis of the average baseline durations of service for each of the posts, so I’m not going to run through that again. Noted also that there are several members of cabinet eligible for retirement at this point without having done anything specifically wrong and that it’s possible that some may fall to ill health. I think the only way to factor in the unpredictability around this at a year out is through an additional margin of error. I guess from a Brier Score point of view it won’t do anyone’s averages any good if there is a freak accident at the Russian cabinet and Senior CEOs annual yacht party.  On the trends picture:  Putin fired a swathe of regional governors last year http://www.rt.com/politics/353733-putin-replaces-heads-of-russian/ and Yakunin was shuffled out of Russian Railways in 2015. He also demoted Sergei Ivanov to Transport & Environment in 2016 http://www.ft.com/content/e9c3b756-60d8-11e6-b38c-7b39cbb1138a
 – easy to see this as part of the trend to replace aging cabinet but there are claims that Ivanov sacked for poor advice/handling of DNC hack http://www.buzzfeed.com/kenbensinger/these-reports-allege-trump-has-deep-ties-to-russia?utm_term=.gx90v4Rvq#.cj5veJle3
 and apparently Yakunin’s corruption was so egregious it pushed even VVP too far http://www.rferl.org/a/russia-railways-yakunin-whistle-blower-corruption/28042893.html, http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/vladimir-putin/11923174/Vladimir-Putin-fires-close-ally-Vladimir-Yakunin-after-son-applied-for-British-citizenship.html. 

Bearing this in mind I’m not convinced that there is a purge of old hands taking place. Although we can build on the base rates, many in Putin’s inner circle have lasted so long because they are trusted, somewhat competent, and loyal members of the clique. The way I would look at this question therefore is to consider who is in a prime position to be moved through general incompetence or unpopularity. Looking at the names on the list, the top contenders are Bastrykin and Medvedev.   Medvedev: 
Reasons he’ll be gone:
1.	He’s unpopular (been covered in previous forecasts by others) http://themoscowtimes.com/articles/Medvedev-is-out-57576
2.	There are potential votes to be gained by sacking an unpopular PM, and Putin may want to demonstrate a direction of movement 
3.	Putin has form in this department (Kasyanov 2004 http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/3521591.stm or Fradkov 2007 , although Putin seems to have personally & politically disliked Kasyanov and was becoming PM in the elections after Fradkov’s removal, so they aren’t exact comparisons) Reasons he might stay:
1.	The stories of his demise have previously been greatly exaggerated... the “Medvedev will get fired soon” story has been swirling for years. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-russia-medvedev-idUSBRE93G0JD20130417 It’s worth noting that his approval numbers were around as bad then as now http://www.levada.ru/en/ratings/. Tim Ash thought he was going to be replaced last year, with Alexei Kudrin (who is still a possibility I’d have thought) http://www.ft.com/content/fdb5a2dd-40a9-3bff-b9b5-c1073ab2a118. (Ash's comments are a good example of the difficulty of timing in forecasting!)
2.	It doesn’t seem that his unpopularity is transferring to Putin based on the numbers. Having someone else as the target of opposition anger isn’t necessarily a bad thing for any politician, and VVP knows where he stands with DAM
3.	Firing him would give succour to Navalny and the opposition, who would surely go for a new target.  Bastrykin: 
Reasons he could be gone:
1.	He’s been a long running PR disaster, attracting negative press for threatening to kill a journalist and maintaining businesses abroad, as well as general accusations of incompetence http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2013/08/the-rise-and-probable-fall-of-putins-enforcer/278577/
2.	Last year his office was raided by the FSBs Economic Security Service suggesting he might have enemies in high places http://themoscowtimes.com/news/investigative-committee-head-denounces-betrayal-of-arrested-colleagues-54712 Bastrykin was widely reported to have resigned in September, post elections. He's still in post, but this doesn't exactly say "long stable tenure ahead".
3.	He has little power base of his own and has annoyed a number of high ranking officials. There have been rumblings about a new state security service, which could take functions from the Investigative Committee.  Reasons he might stay: 
1.	He’s obviously of some use or he would be gone by now given the above. He has patronage from Sechin, although this is considered tepid
2.	He’s been an effective hatchet man for Putin in the past, and having no base of support he is already easy to manage, therefore less likely to be part of any clear out of independent power bases.  Of the remaining figures I can’t see any under specific threat. Alexei Miller appears ostensibly to be doing a decent enough job at Gazprom, and is comparatively young. Igor Sechin, well, if he is toppled, big things are changing. He is a key ally of VVP and ingrained in the Russian system with deep ties to the FSB and patronage over a number of Russia’s ruling class as noted in Bastrykin's case. There is no clear reason I can see that Shoygu would be moved, appears to be popular enough and generally getting on with the job, which is a winning formula if you want to work in the Russian government - any big Syrian reversals could affect his position.  Patrushev seems to have been given Balkan responsibility lately http://www.politico.eu/article/vladimir-putin-balkans-point-man-nikolai-patrushev/ but I’d suggest that’s probably consistent with being seen as someone who is trusted to do a good job – although he is one of the older members of the group I’ve yet to see or hear anything that makes me doubt his position.  So, bearing that in mind, for my thoughts from the perspective of answering the question:  0-1: Possible. I’ve identified two men who have every reason to be moved on. Yet both have survived in difficult circumstances before. Conversely, given the elections and associated political pressures it is more than possible that someone not considered at risk in my analysis could become at risk before July 2018, even if Medvedev and Bastrykin don’t move.  2-3: Also possible, and I think most likely. Loyalty or not, elections are a great time to move troublesome people, and I have identified two which means there is a margin of error upwards built into this bucket, which might be necessary given the long time horizon.  4-5: Less likely. 4-5 leaving would be quite an overhaul and rebalancing of the system – perhaps unprecedented in the time period remaining and the seniority of the figures? Incremental moves at the top would preserve stability better, and I can’t see that 4 of the listed men are in such a precarious position that their moves are necessitated. Conversely, I could imagine that three could be shuffled or fired within the next 12 months, which would suggest a margin of error ought to be considered towards the possibility of a fourth. 6-7: probably only with a change in President or a serious sweeping away of the current system. Even if 6 were moved I don’t see them all leaving the cabinet/CEO roles. I believe there is little chance of this and therefore am satisfied not to put a percentage on it for the moment.

President Putin is slowly removing contemporaries and elders from his inner circle to consolidate leadership of the upcoming generation.   The youngest person in the list is Prime Minister Medvedev and he is 51.  I surmise anyone besides Medvedev is at risk for being forced into early retirement.  I doubt a purge of any sort will happen in Moscow.  Putin is a healthy 64 year old man who wants to rule Russia for a long time.  He is patient and understands the value of stability.
Adjusting slightly for time. Expecting Medvedev, at least, to get knifed at some point, but maybe not until after or in the close run-up to the presidential election.

There was 436 days from the start of the prediction. Zero people listed have been demoted. Start Mar 22, 2017 03:00AM
Closing Jul 1, 2018 04:59PM There is now 326 days left. One and only one of Dmitry Medvedev and the Sergeys will run. If Medvedev is the pick as expected,then automatically both of them have to step down from their current positions in order for him to run. When the pm is dismissed,so is the deputy. The 2018 Russian presidential election will take place on 18 March 2018. Sergey Shoygu
Minister of Defence of Russia Sergey Lavrov
Minister of Foreign Affairs of Russia
Not even 1 has been removed and only 6 months left in this prediction.

Following @Erik Fritzsche Good analysis at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/506543 I love his ratio of Brier to median plus his research as a Ph.D. political scientist. Check him out on Twitter https://twitter.com/ErikFritzsche, his blog https://erikfritzschedotde.wordpress.com/ Facebook, and his research https://tu-dresden.de/gsw/phil/powi/intpol/die-professur/beschaeftigte/ef?set_language=en @Rene @Dsarin
I think Vlad the Shirtless now has pretty much everybody he wants wherever he wants them, so there mayn't be much more shakeup to come.  I am probably wrong about this.
I am amending my probabilities as a result of the price of Brent Crude's declining to a new low trading range amid talk of oversupply into 2018 (beyond?).

Given the terms of tenure for each of these CEO's and some minor shifts in political climate and the simple "Who is gonna piss off Putin next" you have to expect some attrition given his historical patterns.

Base rates of tenure during Putin's reign (1999/2000):
- Prime Minister: 2,75y
- Defense Minister: 6,5y
- Head of Security Council: 2,25y
- Kozak has the longest tenure of the Deputies with 9 years; shortest Mutko (since Oct, 2016); average year of taking over office: 2011 (former office holder's tenure: unknown)
- trend towards longer tenure since Putin's take over of political power in Russia Arguments for replacements of the named top officials:
- replacements in the aftermath or the campaigning of the Presidential Elections in March 2018
- Shoygu, Bastrykin, Patrushev are older than 60: possible retirement, health problems, death
- tenure: all officials named here have a comparatively long tenure (from Miller 16 years to Shoygu und Medvedev 7 years) Arguments agains replacements of the named top officials:
- All positions enlisted seem to be higher than the ones where the recent replacements took place --> higher visibility, less likely to be target of a replacement.
- Defense Minister and Head of Security Council seem to be curcial in current Russian foreign policy (Ukraine, Syria); and the trend in the recent replacements showed some tendency toward officals from the Security community (FSB, Military).
- Sechin and Miller seem to be loyal, powerful, and well performing in crucial areas of regime stability (selling ressources and earning foreign currencies). Given the long time horizon of the question to 1 July 2018 and the upcoming Presidential Elections, forecasting the outcome accurately is very difficult.
- 0 to 1: very unlikely
- 2 to 3: most likely
- 4 to 5: likely, not too much away from "2 to 3"
- 6 to 7: within 13 months to go least unlikely: seemed to be the case in the take over manoever from Putin in 1999/2000
I surmise that Putin likes the 'players' he has on the field.  He is enjoying geopolitical, and to a lesser extent, domestic success. Tough prediction, though....
I total removal of all these positions is unlikely. Possible but unlikely
The Putin shuffle, he keeps dancing and you die.
General guess based on amount of time left.

Medvedev is involved in corruption scandal and therefore is at most risk.  The biggest uncertainty is wether Putin will run for the next term: he can clearly secure his presidency for the next 6 years, but the question  is how will he  retire - as a wiiner or as a result of revolution - Russian economy is in a poor shape and voters are getting poorer every year since annexation of  Crimea.
I think that the Trump ties will take a toll and Putin will make a change just for appearances.

So of the four allies mentioned in the question three are former KGB officials from St. Petersburg and the fourth, Vladimir Yakunin, officially retired; although there is a fun rumor he was forced out after his son applied for British citizenship. With that in mind, of the seven mentioned only Nikolai Patrushev worked in the KGB so I think he is the most likely to go. The rest of these guys are either career bureaucrats or soldiers and lack independent power bases.  Also, one of the oldest strategies for distracting citizens is to fire someone, there is a rich history of French presidents churning through PM's for instance. So I can see Medvedev or Kozak being fired if Putin needs a shakeup.
There's no real reason for additional departures.

Putin always outsmarted his enemies, locally as well as in the West. He particularly outsmarted the US and its former president Obama. Knowing that Trump is unpredictable, he will begin making changes soon in anticipation of more boycotts targeting executives in the Russian industry.

I have a suspicion that our Congress may succeed with imposing further sanctions against the Russian government and several top officials, and that Vlad Putin will make changes just to keep a step ahead. He will change out executives for the purpose of the new ones not being named in the sanctions, so that these specific positions will still have value to him.
Putin will get too frustrated NOT to sack somebody.

With a Russian election scheduled for March 2018 there will certainly be changes. Medvedev has been in too many positions of power to stay and some of the older members on this list will go. Shoygu may be safe and I am not sure about Sechin or Miller. Will need more information to refine this a bit.

Initial thoughts:  There will be a presidential election in Russia in March 2018. While it is not difficult to predict the very probable victor, the question is whether a new presidential term will usher in an overhaul of state officials.    One partial past precedent: Shortly before his election to a second term of office (in 2004) Putin did appoint a new PM (Mikhail Fradkov) as part of a relatively radical overhaul of the government structures (and great reduction in the numebr of ministries): the way this was done seemed to be using a governmental reorganization almost as part of an electoral pledge or ploy. It's not inconcievable something similar could occur shortly before the 2018 presidential election. One other slightly more tangentially related precedent: in his final months as President in 2012, Medvedev dismissed a substantial number of regional governors - mostly slightly secondary positions compared with the seven posts discussed here, but including a couple of great importance eg Mayor of Moscow - as a way of overhauling the state apparatus/personnel. Of these seven officials , several are long-term close allies of Putin: Patrushev has held his current post since 2008, but was director of the FSB since 1999 (indeed, Putin's successor in that role).  Shoigu (often portrayed as a safe pair of hands, even a potential successor to Putin, but his ethnic and religious minority - Buddhist - status maybe count against him there) goes back even further; his current position is since 2012, but he was Minister of Emergency Situations from in an unbroken period from 1991 to 2012. Miller has been Gazprom CEO since 2001. Kozak has held his current position since 2008, but held other senior positions under Putin earlier in the decade.  Sechin has worked with or for Putin since at least the early 1990s when they were involved in St Petersburg City authorities. Considering their ages: Patrushev is the oldest (66) , Medvedev the youngest (52). Other questions: how long do holders of these positions typically stay in post?
Bastrykin (appt 2011) is the first person to hold this specific post. The Gazprom and Rosneft posts are essentially new ones too.  
Russian Ministers of Defence have tended to stay in office between around four to six years over the past 20 years or so, so Shoigu could be vulnerable here. In general there has been something of a stability of cadres in the upper echelons of the Russian state sand state-linked bodies ince Putin first came to power in 2000. But the need to cultivate a younger generation, younger than Medvedev, couid eventually bring sweeping changes.  My initial thoughts are that Bastrykin is probably the most vulnerable; Shoigu  may not stay in his current post, but be moved to another senior role. Not sure Kozak is so essential as he once was.

Since mid-2015, Russian President Vladimir Putin has removed from prominent positions four close allies: Sergei Ivanov, Andrei Belyaninov, Viktor Ivanov, and Vladimir Yakunin Base rate is 4/7 = 57%. But neither Gazprom nor Rosneft are likely to go, with having successfully bypassed the Ukraine and exceeded expectations. Yevgeny Kiselyov, head of the Federal Agency for Mineral Resources, said that Rosneft and Gazprom had managed to double their licenced obligations. “During the past six years, these subsoil users have over fulfilled the volume of the shelf licence obligations by a factor of two,” Kiselyov said.
http://getrussia.com/news/plan_for_shelf_exploration_work_overachieved/ Vladimir Putin: I would like to congratulate you once again on the Bovanenkovo project. It was a big job and the results have been very good.
http://en.kremlin.ru/events/president/news/53758 Both Dmitry's are likely safe, Medvedev has performed well to date.  The resignation of the Prime Minister automatically means the resignation of the whole government as a body.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia Sergey is crucial to signing the peace treaty with Nihon.
http://www.efe.com/efe/english/portada/japan-russia-resume-security-talks-after-3-years/50000260-3212664 That leaves Alexander Bastrykin (Investigative Committee leader) and Nikolai Patrushev (Head, Security Council of Russia) at risk.

It would almost certainly be helpful to know how that last sentence fragment in the Q ("In the event....") would have ended if anybody had finished it.  "In the event that" they do that, how will it be scored?  Anybody who thinks the GJedi will answer this should go ahead and ask; might get lucky.
